}} 'Martin Hussingtree' is a small village situated between Droitwich Spa and
Worcester in the county of Worcestershire, England. It is north of another
village called Fernhill Heath. It is situated on a junction of the A38 and
A4538. There is a public house called "The Swan" in the village and is located
just north of the junction.

Its church contains the grave of Thomas Tomkins, a composer of sacred music
under Elizabeth I and James I.

Richard Pearce currently plays a huge role, again after a short absence, in
maintaining the church and ensuring its longevity albeit a fight against the
parocial red tape. The church is made of sand stone and is being eatern by mason
bees which are also in decline - so the balance to preserve both is difficult to
maintain. A recent addition of a toilet and sink within the church has added the
diversity of the uses of the building which lends host to larger congregations
and addition church activities.
